[http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117997431.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 "Jennifer Lopez going with 'Plan B': CBS Films seeking director for project"], '[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', December 15, 2008 It was released theatrically in the U.S. on April 23, 2010, and later in other regions.[http://www.theback-upplan.com/ Official website]. Retrieved March 11, 2010. This was [[Tom Bosley]]'s final acting role before his death in October that year. ==Plot== Zoe ([[Jennifer Lopez]]) gives up on finding the man of her dreams, decides to become a single mother and undergoes artificial insemination. The same day she meets Stan ([[Alex O'Loughlin]]) when they both try to hail the same taxi. They run into each other twice more at a farmers market and a pet store. Stan convinces Zoe to go on a no-obligations date. Zoe is still uncertain whether she is pregnant or not and if she should tell Stan. The night she takes the test, Stan takes her for a romantic dinner in a garden. Things don't turn out as well as planned when he spills the wine and a fire occurs. At the end of the night Stan asks her to come to his farm during the weekend and Zoe finds out that she is pregnant. She goes to the farm determined to tell him that she is pregnant. They have sex and afterwards Stan is confused and angry that she didn't tell him before and Zoe leaves the next morning believing that things are over between them. However, Stan decides he still wants to be with her and they reconcile. They go to the doctor and find out that Zoe is actually carrying twins. Overwhelmed, Stan goes to a children's playing area to figure out what it means to be a father, but is suspected to be a pervert; this is soon cleared up. He finds a friend there that he can talk to about the pregnancy throughout the movie, while Zoe gets little support from her Single Mothers and Proud group when the group members discover she is no longer single. Stan takes the next step to becoming a father and orders a stroller for the twins. After many misunderstandings and comedic revelations, Zoe and Stan are walking into the Market when they run into Stan's ex-girlfriend. Due to Stan's remark that the twins are not his, Zoe believes that he is not ready to become a father to them, and breaks off the relationship. Later, the stroller that Stan ordered arrives and Zoe figures out that Stan was never planning to leave. At her grandmother's wedding, Zoe's water breaks and on the way to the hospital they make a pit stop at the Market. Zoe apologizes to Stan and they begin to work things out. He pulls out the penny that she turned over when they first met and Zoe promises to trust him more. Zoe gives birth to twin girls, one of whom they name Penny. In the end, Stan opens a store/restaurant next to Zoe's pet shop and after the Grand Opening speech Stan asks Zoe to marry him and she says yes. On their way home, she spontaneously throws up into a trash can and realizes that she may be yet again pregnant. ==Cast== {{Div col}} * [[Jennifer Lopez]] as Zoe * [[Alex O'Loughlin]] as Stan * [[Michaela Watkins]] as Mona * [[Melissa McCarthy]] as Carol * [[Danneel Harris]] as Olivia * [[Linda Lavin]] as Nana * [[Eric Christian Olsen]] as Clive * [[Anthony Anderson]] as Playground Dad * [[Noureen DeWulf]] as Daphne * [[Rowan Blanchard]] as Monas' daughter * [[Tom Bosley]] as Arthur * [[Maribeth Monroe]] as Lori * [[Peggy Miley]] as Shirley * [[Jennifer Elise Cox]] as Babyland Salesgirl * [[Cesar Millan]] as himself {{Div col end}} == Production == The film, originally titled ''Plan B'', was written by Kate Angelo and produced by Todd Black, Jason Blumenthal and Steve Tisch.{{cite web|last=Fleming|first=Michael|title=Jennifer Lopez going with 'Plan B'|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117997431/?refCatId=13|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|accessdate=January 18, 2013|date=December 15, 2008}} Lopez's casting was announced in December 2008 by multiple sources.{{cite web|last=Zeitchik|first=Steven|title=Jennifer Lopez pencils in 'Plan B'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/jennifer-lopez-pencils-plan-b-124452|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=January 18, 2013|date=December 15, 2008}}{{cite web|last=Grossberg|first=Josh|title=Jennifer Lopez Opts for Plan B|url=http://au.eonline.com/news/73565/jennifer-lopez-opts-for-plan-b|publisher=[[E! Online]], [[NBCUniversal]]|accessdate=January 18, 2013|date=December 16, 2008}} [[Digital Spy]] announced in February 2009 that [[Alan Poul]] was in "final talks" to direct ''Plan B'', which would be his first feature film.{{cite web|last=Reynolds|first=Simon|title=Poul circles Jennifer Lopez's 'Blan B'|url=http://www.digitalspy.com.au/movies/news/a145495/poul-circles-jennifer-lopezs-plan-b.html|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hachette Filipacchi UK]]|accessdate=January 18, 2013|date=February 4, 2009}} On April 8, 2009, ''[[The Arizona Republic]]'' reported that O'Loughlin was "in negotiations to nab the romantic male lead".{{cite web|last=Kit|first=Borys|title=Alex O'Loughlin eyes 'Back-Up Plan'|url=http://www.azcentral.com/thingstodo/movies/articles/2009/04/08/20090408oloughlin0408.html?nclick_check=1|work=[[The Arizona Republic]]|publisher=[[Gannett Company]]|accessdate=January 18, 2013|date=April 8, 2009}} ''The Back-up Plan'' was Lopez's first film in three years, and she confessed to feeling "really nervous".{{cite web|last=Lara|first=Martin|title=Lopez 'worried about forgetting how to act'|url=http://www.digitalspy.com.au/showbiz/news/a158166/lopez-worried-about-forgetting-how-to-act.html|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hachette Filipacchi UK]]|accessdate=January 18, 2013|date=June 5, 2009}} Filming began on May 11, 2009, in [[Los Angeles, California]]. The film was also filmed in [[Pasadena, California]] where Lopez was spotted wearing her prosthetic pregnancy belly.{{cite web|title=Magic of movies: Jennifer Lopez goes from a flat stomach to heavily pregnant overnight|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1193321/Magic-movies-Jennifer-Lopez-goes-flat-stomach-heavily-pregnant-overnight.html|work=[[Daily Mail]]|publisher=[[Associated Newspapers Ltd]]|accessdate=January 18, 2013|date=June 17, 2009}} The film's production budget was $35 million.{{cite web|last=Horn|first=John|title=Word of Mouth: Jennifer Lopez makes an acting comeback in ‘The Back-Up Plan’|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/apr/22/entertainment/la-et-word-20100422|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|publisher=[[Tribune Company]]|accessdate=January 18, 2013|date=April 22, 2010}} ===Music=== The soundtrack and the score were released on March 26, 2010 on [[iTunes]].{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/be/album/the-back-up-plan-original/id362602252&partnerId=30&siteID=X3Th4gZi_iQ-iaZb2VWmXvU29h419c6rTQ |title=The Back-up Plan (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack) by Various Artists - Download The Back-up Plan (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack) on iTunes |publisher=Itunes.apple.com |date=2010-04-13 |accessdate=2010-09-11}}{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/be/album/the-back-up-plan-original/id364086887&partnerId=30&siteID=X3Th4gZi_iQ-_bco1AM5wAQyD_KZ5ugSVQ |title=The Back-up Plan (Original Motion Picture Score) by Stephen Trask - Download The Back-up Plan (Original Motion Picture Score) on iTunes |publisher=Itunes.apple.com |date=2010-04-13 |accessdate=2010-09-11}} They are available on [[Amazon.com]] since April 13, 2010. The soundtrack has various artists, while the score was composed entirely by [[Stephen Trask]].{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B003BLUE1A |title=The Back-up Plan: The Back-up Plan: Music |publisher=Amazon.com |date=2009-09-09 |accessdate=2010-03-20}} ===Soundtrack=== {{tracklist | headline = ''The Back-up Plan (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)''{{cite web|url=https://itun.es/gb/m8nNv|title=iTunes - Music - The Back-up Plan (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack) by Various Artists|publisher=[[iTunes Store]] (GB)}} | extra_column = Artist(s) | title1 = [[(What Is) Love?|What Is Love?]] | extra1 = [[Jennifer Lopez]] | length1 = 4:27 | title2 = Say Hey (I Love You) | extra2 = [[Michael Franti & Spearhead]] | length2 = 3:39 | title3 = Fallin' For You | extra3 = [[Colbie Caillat]] | length3 = 3:36 | title4 = Disco Lies | extra4 = [[Moby]] | length4 = 3:32 | title5 = A Beautiful Day | extra5 = [[India.Arie]] | length5 = 3:51 | title6 = Key to My Heart | extra6 = Jessica Jarrell | length6 = 3:54 | title7 = Crabbuckit | extra7 = [[K-os]] | length7 = 3:40 | title8 = Bottles | extra8 = [[V V Brown]] | length8 = 3:02 | title9 = You Me & the Bourgeoisie | extra9 = [[The Submarines]] | length9 = 3:22 | title10 =Let's Finish | note10 = Sinden Remix | extra10 = [[Kudu]] | length10 = 4:48 | title11 = Daydream | note11 = Titles Theme from ''The Back-up Plan'' | extra11 = [[Stephen Trask]] | length11 = 2:25 | title12 = She Drives Me Crazy | note12 = bonus track | extra12 = Raney Shockne featuring Barbara Perry | length12 = 3:14 | title13 = What a Wonderful World | note13 = bonus track | extra13 = Raney Shockne featuring Barbara Perry | length13 = 2:36 }} ===Score=== The [[Film score|film's score]] was composed by [[Stephen Trask]]. {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} # Daydream – 2:25 # The Back Up Plan – 1:05 # Now What? – 1:04 # That Guy – 0:43 # Show Me Your Cheese – 0:24 # Goodbye for Now – 0:22 # Another Penny Drops – 1:28 # Pregnancy Test – 1:31 # Community Garden – 1:40 # A Serious Question – 0:43 # Fire – 0:40 # First Kiss – 1:01 # Test Results – 0:13 # Shadybrook – 0:38 # Mirror, Mirror – 1:02 # Yummy, Yummy – 1:05 # Cheese Muse – 1:15 {{col-2}} # Orgasm – 1:01 # Telling the Truth – 1:46 # Not Leaving Leaving – 0:33 # Dejected – 0:24 # Here We Go – 0:35 # Studies – 0:19 # Chicken In Your Hair – 0:39 # Pancake Prelude – 0:28 # Are You Still In There? – 2:56 # Wall of Strollers / Examination – 1:48 # Pictures of Mom – 1:32 # Just Go – 2:40 # I Wanted a Baby – 1:03 # Old Dogs-New Tricks – 0:43 # Baby Time – 0:43 # And Now, for the Exciting Conclusion Of – 4:49 # Proposal – 1:13 {{col-end}} ==Release== ===Box office=== The film was moderately a box office success. ''The Back-up Plan'' earned $4,257,676 in 3,280 theaters on its Friday debut, but managed to make #1 at the box office.{{Cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=daily&id=backupplan.htm |title=The Back-Up Plan |work=Box Office Mojo }}{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=2736&p=.htm |title=Friday Report: 'Back-Up Plan' Tops the Day, 'Dragon' to Top the Weekend |publisher=Box Office Mojo |date=2010-04-24 |accessdate=2010-09-11}} It dropped to #2 at the weekend box office with a gross of $12,201,710, averaging $3,720 per theater.{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=backupplan.htm |title=The Back-Up Plan (2010) |publisher=Box Office Mojo |date=2010-07-22 |accessdate=2010-09-11}} In its 2nd week it dropped to #4 with $7,255,762, averaging $2,212 per theater.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=2751&p=.htm |title=Weekend Report: 'Nightmare' Wakes Up in Top Spot |publisher=Box Office Mojo |date=2010-05-03 |accessdate=2010-09-11}} In its 3rd week the film dropped to #5 grossing $5,033,471, averaging $1,676 per theater.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/weekend/chart/ |title=Weekend Box Office Results for September 3–5, 2010 |publisher=Box Office Mojo |date= |accessdate=2010-09-11}} The following week it dropped to #6 grossing $2,387,480, averaging $956 per theater. As of July 14, it had grossed $77,237,270 worldwide, and is [[CBS Films]]' highest-grossing film to date.{{Cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/studio/chart/?studio=cbsfilms.htm |title=Box Office by Studie: CBS Films |work=Box Office Mojo }}{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/2010/PLANB.php |title=The Back-up Plan - Box Office Data, Movie News, Cast Information |publisher=The Numbers |date= |accessdate=2010-09-11}} ''The Back-up Plan'' reached #1 on Top Ten Hot Movies On Demand.{{citation needed|date=January 2013}} ===Critical response=== The film received negative reviews from critics, with most critics panning the script, but reacting positively to Lopez's performance. [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reported that 18% of critics gave the film positive reviews based on 145 reviews with an average score of 3.6/10.{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/back_up_plan/ | title=The Back-up Plan Movie Reviews, Pictures | work=Rotten Tomatoes | publisher=[[Fandango (company)|Fandango]] | accessdate=November 30, 2018}} Its consensus states "Jennifer Lopez is as appealing as ever, but ''The Back-up Plan'' smothers its star with unrelatable characters and a predictable plot." Another review aggretator, [[Metacritic]], which assigns a [[weighted mean|weighted average]] from 0 to 100 on top reviews of mainstream critics, gave the film an average score of 34% based on 32 reviews.{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/film/titles/backupplan | title=Back-up Plan, The reviews at Metacritic.com | work=Metacritic | publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] Inc. | accessdate=2010-04-22}} Kirk Honeycutt of ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' gave the film a positive review saying, "A winning performance by Jennifer Lopez overcomes a formulaic and predictable rom-com that involves a planned pregnancy."{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/film-reviews/the-back-up-plan-film-review-1004080985.story | title=The Back-Up Plan -- Film Review | author=Honeycutt, Kirk | date=2010-04-07 | work=The Hollywood Reporter}} ''[[The New York Times]]'' film critic [[Manohla Dargis]] wrote that the film is "not very good" and "bland".{{cite web|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/2010/04/23/movies/23backup.html?8dpc | title=Movie Review - The Back-Up Plan - Love Means Having to Say, ‘I Feel ...’ | author=Dargis, Manohla | date=2010-04-22 | work=The New York Times | publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]}} Amy Biancolli of the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' praised the cast in her review writing "Lopez does a fine job mortifying herself in pursuit of physical humor, shifting her center of gravity in more ways than one. O'Loughlin, in the blander role, acts hurt or shocked or besotted where required, but the supporting players nearly steal the show."{{cite web |url= http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2010/04/22/MVIK1D27U9.DTL#ixzz0lywtVyTa |author= Biancolli, Amy |title= Review: 'The Back-Up Plan' |work=San Francisco Chronicle |publisher=[[Hearst Corporation]], Inc. |accessdate= 2010-04-23 |date= 2010-04-23}} ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' film critic [[Roger Ebert]] gave the film 1/4 stars, claiming the film "plays like an unendurable TV commercial about beautiful people with great lifestyles and not a thought in their empty little heads."{{cite web |url= http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20100421/REVIEWS/100429995 | author= Ebert, Roger |title=The Back-up Plan :: rogerebert.com :: Reviews |publisher=[[Sun-Times Media]] |work= rogerebert.com | date=2010-04-21 |accessdate= 2010-04-23}} Jennifer Lopez received 2 nominations for Best Romantic Comedy Actress and Best Romantic Comedy for The Back-Up Plan at the Teen Choice Awards. ===Home media=== ''The Back-up Plan'' was released on August 24, 2010 on [[DVD]] and [[Blu-ray Disc|Blu-ray]] and sold 277,183 ( $4.7 million) copies in its first week of release debuting at #2 on the charts behind the sixth season of ''[[Lost (TV series)|Lost]]''.{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}} ''The Back-up Plan'' also ranked #1 at both the Top 10 Renting DVD Titles and Top 10 Selling DVD Titles at U.S. BLOCKBUSTER stores, as well as #1 at the Top 10 Online Renting DVD Titles at Blockbuster.com. #3 at Top 10 Renting Blu-ray Titles at U.S. BLOCKBUSTER stores, #1 at Top 10 Selling Digital Titles on BLOCKBUSTER On Demand.{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/the-back-up-plan-tops-weekly-blockbusterr-hit-list-of-top-10-renting-dvds-101907228.html |title='The Back-Up Plan' Tops Weekly BLOCKBUSTER(k) Hit List of Top 10 Renting DVDs - DALLAS, Aug. 31 /PRNewswire/ |location=Texas |publisher=Prnewswire.com |date= |accessdate=2010-09-11}}. ''The Back-up Plan'' also reached #1 on Top Movie Sales on iTunes.{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.theback-upplan.com|The Back-up Plan}} * {{IMDb title|1212436|The Back-up Plan}} * {{Amg movie|490905|The Back-up Plan}} * {{Mojo title|backupplan|The Back-up Plan}} * {{Rotten Tomatoes|back_up_plan|The Back-up Plan}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Back-Up Plan}} [[Category:2010s romantic comedy films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American romantic comedy films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Pregnancy films]] [[Category:CBS Films films]] [[Category:Films scored by Stephen Trask]]

[[Stephanie Germain|Stephanie Germain Productions]] | distributor = [[NBC]] | released = February 18, 2001 | runtime = 82 minutes | country = [[United States]] | language = [[English language|English]] }} '''''The Princess and the Marine''''' is a [[2001 in film|2001]] [[Cinema of the United States|American]] [[Television film|made-for-television]] [[Romance film|romantic movie]] based on the true story of [[United States Marine Corps|American Marine]] Jason Johnson and [[Bahrain]] [[Princess]] [[Meriam Al-Khalifa]], with stars [[Mark-Paul Gosselaar]] and [[Marisol Nichols]] in the roles of Jason and Meriam. ==Plot== [[Meriam Al Khalifa]] ([[Marisol Nichols]]) is a Bahraini royal who is not content to be in an arranged marriage, even though her strict [[Muslim]] parents would never allow a union with a non-Muslim. In the movie, Meriam is allowed to go to the local mall and watch and listen to American [[pop culture]]. One day, she desperately makes some random calls to strangers, including a Marine stationed at the U.S. embassy named Jason Johnson ([[Mark-Paul Gosselaar]]). After meeting, the two become friends and later fall in love, but Meriam doesn't tell anyone because of her parents. After being caught kissing at the [[Tree of Life (Bahrain)|Tree of Life]], her mother forbids any more contact between the two. Meriam and Jason exchange letters with the help of a jeweler in the mall, and plan to run away to America with a fake passport for Meriam and pass her off as a fellow Marine. Once in America, Meriam is taken in by the local authorities for being an illegal immigrant and is separated from Jason. Meriam is released after asking for [[political asylum|asylum]], saying she'd be disowned or even killed if she returned to Bahrain. Meriam and Jason marry in Las Vegas, and he is stripped of his insignia and rank to Private in the Marines. The film concludes with Meriam and Jason stationed at a base, looking outside at an American flag, while a Marine holding a copy of the [[Quran]] salutes. It is then that Meriam tells Jason that this is what she believes in (America - freedom). ==Cast== *[[Mark-Paul Gosselaar]] as Jason Johnson *[[Marisol Nichols]] as Meriam Al-Khalifa *Luck Hari as Meriam's mother *Alexis Lopes as Latifa *[[Keith Robinson (actor)|Keith Robinson]] as Trucker *[[Sheetal Sheth]] as Layla ==Awards/Nominations== Marisol Nichols was nominated for [[ALMA Awards]]-Outstanding Actress for her role in this movie.[[Marisol Nichols]] ==See also== *[[Meriam Al Khalifa]] *[[House of Khalifa]] *[[Bahrain]] *[[Tree of Life, Bahrain]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title |tt0272255}} *[http://mytruestory.com/story/87 Interview with Meriam Al Khalifa] *[https://www.twitter.com/__Meriam__ Meriam Al Khalifa on Twitter] {{DEFAULTSORT:Princess and the Marine}} [[Category:2001 films]] [[Category:2001 television films]] [[Category:2000s romantic drama films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American television films]] [[Category:American romantic drama films]] [[Category:Romance television films]] [[Category:Interfaith romance films]] [[Category:Romance films based on actual events]] [[Category:Films about princesses]] [[Category:Films about the United States Marine Corps]] [[Category:Films shot in California]] [[Category:Films set in Bahrain]] [[Category:Films set in the Las Vegas Valley]]

{{Infobox theatre group | name = Theatreworks USA | image = | imagesize = | caption = | formed = {{Start date|1961}} | disbanded = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | genre = Children's theatre | location = New York City | members = | ArtisticDirector = | notable = | homepage = {{URL|http://www.theatreworksusa.org}} }}
'''Theatreworks USA''' is a professional, not-for-profit [[theatre]] for young and family audiences founded in 1961. The company is based out of [[New York City]], but has touring productions that run through forty-nine states as well as parts of [[Canada]]. Plays and musicals produced by Theatreworks have reached over 90 million children, teachers and families since the company's founding.
==Free Summer Theatre==
Since 1989 Theatreworks USA's Free Summer Theatre has provided young people and families with original, professional theatre free of charge. Each summer, tickets are distributed to [[children]] in over 200 social service and youth programs throughout the [[five boroughs]]. To date, over 300,000 children have attended free productions of some of the company's most popular shows, including ''[[Junie B. Jones]]'', ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'', and ''[[Sarah, Plain and Tall]]''. According to its own literature, Theatreworks believes "all children should experience the excitement of going to the theatre, regardless of their financial circumstances." Roma Torre, a [[NY1]] reporter, has said the following of the program:<ref>NY1 News; 2006-07-20; ''[http://www.ny1.com/content/pages/61180/where-to-go---if-you-give-a-mouse-a-cookie---arthur-s-great-summer--dirty-sock-funtime-band Where To Go: "If You Give A Mouse A Cookie," Arthur's Great Summer, Dirty Sock Funtime Band]''; NY1; Retrieved 2013-09-06.</ref>
{{quote|TWUSA has done it again. Not only is the company's latest production yet another extremely delightful book adaptation for children—it's free. It's one splendid hour of music, laughter, life lessons and the art of putting on a show.}}
Theatreworks USA's production of ''[[The Civil War (play)|The Civil War]]'' made its Off-Broadway debut at the [[Lucille Lortel Theatre]] for the 2013 Free Summer Theatre program. ''The Civil War'' ran from July 15, 2013 until August 16, 2013.<ref>http://www.lortel.org/lla_archive/index.cfm?search_by=show&id=6193</ref>
== Managed artists ==
In addition to their plays and musicals, Theatreworks USA offers educational presentations by artists and groups, for school and public performances. Included are historical productions, as well as stories, songs and dance from many cultures featuring authentic artists who entertain as well as teach about their traditions.<ref>[http://www.theatreworksusa.org/home.cfm?selectedTab=3&selectedSeason=ma TheatreworksUSA - Managed Artists]</ref>
==Alumni artists== Theatreworks has a history of giving young actors, writers, directors, and designers their first professional break. Amongst the alumni are four-time [[Tony Award]] winning director [[Jerry Zaks]], Robert Jess Roth (''[[Beauty and the Beast (musical)|Beauty and the Beast]]''), [[Michael Mayer (director)|Michael Mayer]] (''[[Thoroughly Modern Millie (play)|Thoroughly Modern Millie]]''), Gabriel Barre; writers [[Marta Kauffman]] and [[David Crane (producer)|David Crane]] (TV's "[[Friends]]"), [[Lynn Ahrens]] and [[Stephen Flaherty]] (''[[Ragtime (musical)|Ragtime]]'', ''[[Once on This Island]]''), [[Jason Robert Brown]] (''[[Parade (musical)|Parade]]''), [[Laurence O'Keefe (composer)|Larry O'Keefe]] (''[[Bat Boy: The Musical]]''), [[Robert Lopez]] and [[Jeff Marx]] (''[[Avenue Q]]''); [[Kristen Anderson-Lopez]] (Disney's ''[[Frozen (2013 film)|Frozen]]'', with Lopez); and Tony-winning actors [[Roger Bart]], [[Chuck Cooper (actor)|Chuck Cooper]], [[John Lloyd Young]], and [[John Glover (actor)|John Glover]]. Esteemed performers [[Jesse Tyler Ferguson]], [[F. Murray Abraham]], [[Daphne Rubin-Vega]], [[Henry Winkler]], [[Kathryn Boule]] and [[Judy Kuhn]] also got their start with Theatreworks.
==Awards== Theatreworks has won many awards in its long history.<ref>[http://www.theatreworksusa.org/history_awards.cfm TheatreworksUSA - Awards, Honors, and Recognitions for TheatreworksUSA]</ref> Some of these honors include:
*2010 [[Drama Desk Award]] Nominee for Outstanding Lyrics for [[Click, Clack, Moo: Cows That Type|''Click, Clack, Moo'']]. *2010 [[Lucille Lortel]] Award Nominee for Outstanding Musical and Outstanding Choreography for [[Click, Clack, Moo: Cows That Type|''Click, Clack, Moo'']]. *2008 [[Lucille Lortel]] Award Nominee for Outstanding Revival, Outstanding Choreography and Outstanding Costumes for ''[[Seussical]]''. *2008 [[Drama League Award]] Nominee for Outstanding Revival of a Musical for ''[[Seussical]]''. *2005 [[Lucille Lortel]] Award Nominee for Best Musical and Best Choreography for ''[[Junie B. Jones]]''. *2001 [[Jonathan Larson Performing Arts Foundation]] Award for "artistic vision and commitment to the support and development of theatre artists." *1996 [[Drama Desk Award]] given by New York theatre critics for Theatreworks' "35 years of providing quality entertainment to children and their parents. *1996 [[Lucille Lortel]] Award given by Off Broadway theatres and producers, for "Outstanding Special Achievement." *1996 Staw Hat Award for Best Play awarded to ''The Color of Justice''. *1984 [[AUDELCO]] Award at the Twelfth Annual Black Theatre Awards for ''Play to Win'', a musical about [[Jackie Robinson]] breaking the color barrier in major league [[baseball]]. The award was for "best writing of a new show by black authors for the non-commercial theatre."
==Chelsea Studios== In 2000, Theatreworks established Chelsea Studios, a rehearsal studio in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan.<ref>[http://www.theatreworksusa.org/chelsea.cfm#TESTIMONIALS Chelsea Studios / TheatreworksUSA]</ref><ref>[https://www.facebook.com/ChelseaStudiosTWUSA Facebook - Chelsea Studios]</ref> In addition to providing a rehearsal space for Theatreworks's productions, Chelsea also rents its studios out to casting agents, touring productions, exercise classes, and various other clients.

{{Infobox Theatre |name = Theatre Royal |image = File:Theatre Royal, Newcastle.jpg |caption = Façade of the Theatre Royal |address = Grey Street |city = [[Newcastle upon Tyne]] |country = |designation = [[Listed building|Grade I]] |coordinates = {{coord|54.97278|-1.61194|type:landmark|display=inline}} |architect = John and Benjamin Green |owner = Theatre Royal Trust |capacity = 1,249 total seat capacity across four levels |type = Major regional theatre |opened = 20 February 1837 |yearsactive = |rebuilt = 1901 [[Frank Matcham]] |othernames = |production = Visiting productions |currentuse = |website = http://www.theatreroyal.co.uk }} The '''Theatre Royal''' is a historic theatre, a Grade I [[listed building]] situated on [[Grey Street, Newcastle|Grey Street]] in [[Newcastle upon Tyne]].
==History== The theatre was designed by local architects [[John and Benjamin Green]] as part of [[Richard Grainger]]'s grand design for the centre of Newcastle, and was opened on 20 February 1837 with a performance of ''[[The Merchant of Venice]]''.<ref name ="chronicle">{{cite web|url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/news/history/happy-180th-birthday-newcastles-magnificent-12620352|date=20 February 2017|title=Happy 180th birthday to Newcastle's magnificent Theatre Royal|publisher=The Chronicle|accessdate=25 March 2018}}</ref> One of the first managers here was Thomas Ternan who employed his wife, [[Frances Eleanor Jarman|Frances Ternan]] as the main actress.<ref name=spart>[http://spartacus-educational.com/ARTternanT.htm Thomas Ternan], John Simkin, Spartacus Educational, retrieved 19 January 2015</ref>
The shareholders of the Proprietors` Committee appointed lessees to manage and programme the theatre. The longest running individual lessee, before Ltd companies, was Edward D Davis from 1845 to 1870 during which in 1867 the interior was redesigned by architect [[Charles J. Phipps]].<ref>http://www.arthurlloyd.co.uk/Newcastle/TheatreRoyalNewcastle.htm#gs</ref> William Glover and George Francis, both of the [[Theatre Royal, Glasgow]] took over from 1871 to 1878; to be followed by Charles Bernard of the [[Gaiety Theatre, Glasgow]] until 1882. James Howard and Fred Wyndham of Edinburgh and Glasgow became lessees from 1883 to 1887. Due to their intention, carried out, of also leasing the [[Tyne Theatre and Opera House]], the shareholder committee did not renew their lease of the Royal. <ref>http://www.arthurlloyd.co.uk/Newcastle/TheatreRoyalNewcastle.htm#gs</ref>
Instead, Robert Arthur of Glasgow and now lessee of [[Her Majesty`s Theatre, Dundee]] took over in 1888.<ref>http://www.arthurlloyd.co.uk/Dundee/HerMajestysTheatreDundee.htm</ref> After the fire of 1899 he instructed architect Frank Matcham to totally redesign the interior, re-opening in 1901. The venues of Robert Arthur Theatres Ltd in Scotland and England, which had many shareholders in Tyneside, prospered until losses overwhelmed the company in 1911.<ref>Graeme Smith (2008),''The Theatre Royal: Entertaining a Nation'', Glasgow Publications, 2008 {{ISBN|978-0-9559420-0-6}}</ref> At this point the Arthur shareholders, led by the family of [[Joseph Cowen]] MP, appointed a new chairman of the lessee company, Michael Simons, of Glasgow, who in 1895 had created [[Howard & Wyndham Ltd]]. <ref>http://www.arthurlloyd.co.uk/Newcastle/TheatreRoyalNewcastle.htm#gs</ref>
From 1912 onwards the Theatre Royal Newcastle was an important part of the [[Howard & Wyndham]] group, led successfully by chairman Simons, followed by the Cruikshank family, whose [[King's Theatre, Edinburgh]] joined the group in 1928. Newcastle City Council took over ownership in 1967. <ref>http://www.arthurlloyd.co.uk/Newcastle/TheatreRoyalNewcastle.htm#gs</ref><ref>Graeme Smith (2008),''The Theatre Royal: Entertaining a Nation'', Glasgow Publications, 2008 {{ISBN|978-0-9559420-0-6}}</ref>
Newcastle, Glasgow and Edinburgh formed a triangle of industry, commerce and entertainment business from the 1870s onwards. From 1962 and increasingly from the 1970s the interchange of shows and pantomimes was joined by tours each year of [[Scottish Opera]] and of [[Scottish Ballet]]. [[Opera North]] joined in.<ref>http://www.arthurlloyd.co.uk/Newcastle/TheatreRoyalNewcastle.htm#gs</ref> <ref>Graeme Smith (2008), ''The Theatre Royal: Entertaining a Nation'', Glasgow Publications, 2008 {{ISBN|978-0-9559420-0-6}}</ref>
Following a performance of [[William Shakespeare]]'s play ''[[Macbeth]]'', a huge fire destroyed the interior of the building in 1899.<ref>{{cite web|last=Butcher |first=Joanne |url=http://www.thejournal.co.uk/news/north-east-news/newcastle-theatre-royal-set-35m-4477317 |title=Newcastle Theatre Royal set for £3.5m restoration |publisher=The Journal |date= |accessdate=2015-11-18}}</ref> It had its interior redesigned by [[Frank Matcham]]<ref name = "guardian">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/the-northerner/2011/sep/09/theatre-royal-newcastle-frank-matcham-grey-street-wakefield-blackpool-firth-carpets|date=9 September 2011|publisher=The Guardian|title=Geordieland's theatrical phoenix spreads its bright new wings|accessdate=25 March 2018}}</ref> and reopened on 31 December 1901.<ref name ="chronicle"/> Externally, the building is exactly as it was when it was first built.
It underwent a major refurbishment and restoration in the latter part of the 1980s, reopening on 11 January 1988 with a performance of ''[[A Man For All Seasons]]'' starring [[Charlton Heston]].
The Theatre Royal went dark on 14 March 2011 due to a major restoration of the auditorium, box office, bars and restaurant. The restoration restored the theatre to the original 1901 [[Frank Matcham]] [[Edwardian]] interior. The whole interior was stripped apart from the original plasterwork which was carefully preserved. The [[proscenium]] arch, tiers and boxes were gold leafed and the plasterwork restored. On all levels the seats were replaced with Edwardian-style theatre seats in keeping with the restoration. The amphitheatre which was removed during previous renovations was restored to offer more leg room and better views than the gallery. This took the theatre to five distinct seating areas, the stalls, grand circle, upper circle, amphitheatre and gallery. Wheelchair spaces were installed on levels which had previously been inaccessible. As well as the boxes near the stage, boxes at the rear of the grand and upper circles were also restored taking the total number of boxes up to ten. The stage lift and orchestra pit were replaced to offer better facilities for [[opera]] and [[musicals]]. A new ventilation system was put in place to improve comfort levels in the theatre. New [[frescos]] for the lobby and upper circle were commissioned and put in place. This £4.75m project introduced higher standards of comfort and improved energy. The Theatre Royal reopened on 12 September 2011 with [[Alan Bennett]]’s epic period drama ''[[The Madness of George III]]'';<ref name = "guardian"/> [[George III]] was in fact the monarch who gave the Theatre Royal its charter.
The theatre currently hosts a variety of shows, including ballet, contemporary dance, drama, musicals and opera.The Christmas [[pantomime]] is one of the UK's most popular.
Almost all of the shows that come to the Theatre Royal are part of national British tours, and in a typical year the theatre will have 30 to 35 visiting shows. For the annual pantomime, and any visiting musicals and opera performances, there is a sizeable orchestra pit available which can seat 60 musicians if necessary. The stage itself is also of substantial size, and can house 50 singers, dancers, actors and musicians.
==The Original Theatre Royal== Newcastle's original Theatre Royal opened on 21 January 1788.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.british-history.ac.uk/no-series/newcastle-historical-account/pp229-231 |title=Public buildings: The Theatre Royal | British History Online |publisher=British-history.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-11-18}}</ref> Its location on Mosley Street obstructed plans for the redevelopment of the city centre (as it was on the route of [[Grey Street, Newcastle|Grey Street]]), so it was demolished to make way for the present building. One of the theatre's most successful managers at this time was [[Stephen Kemble]] of the famous [[Kemble family]],<ref>https://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/news/north-east-news/18th-century-newcastle-theatre-royal-8635356</ref> who managed the theatre from 1791 to 1806. The original theatre's final performance was on 25 June 1836.
==Technical details== The current theatre has a [[proscenium stage]], and accommodates a variable orchestra pit on 2 lifts - which reduces the stall seating. The audience is seated on four levels: stalls (501), grand circle (252), upper circle (249) and gallery (247).
==Project A== Project A is a one-year actor training programme led by an artistic director and supported by leading industry specialists. Delivered from within the Theatre Royal over an academic year (3 terms) participants gain professional standard actor training culminating in a production term to be performed in the Studio Theatre and toured nationally.
The course started in September 2015 with the first year free for the successful actors. The programme is seen as an alternative to drama school and is expected to lift the actors involved into the industry.
The [[Royal Shakespeare Company]] have very strong ties to the theatre and are involved with the programme heavily in the second term.<ref>[http://www.theatreroyal.co.uk/taking-part/project-a Theatre Royal] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150912125220/http://www.theatreroyal.co.uk/taking-part/project-a |date=12 September 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Hodgson |first=Barbara |url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/whats-on/whats-on-news/newcastle-theatre-royal-launches-young-9398928 |title=Newcastle Theatre Royal launches young actor training scheme |publisher=Chronicle Live |date=2015-06-05 |accessdate=2015-11-18}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.theatreroyal.co.uk/}} *[https://www.theatreroyal.co.uk/about/our-history History page at the Official Site] * [http://www.arthurlloyd.co.uk/Newcastle/TheatreRoyalNewcastle.htm Theatre Royal History] * [http://www.thetheatre.org/theatre-royal-newcastle History of The Theatre Royal] * [http://www.ntrproject-a.co.uk Theatre Royal, Project A] {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2011}}

{{Infobox Painting| image_file=Time_transfixed.jpg | backcolor=#FBF5DF | painting_alignment=right | image_size=300px | title=La Durée poignardée (Time Transfixed) | artist=[[René Magritte]] | year=1938 | medium=[[Oil painting|Oil on canvas]] | height_metric=147 | width_metric=98.7 | height_imperial=57.87 | width_imperial=38.86 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=[[Chicago]] | museum=[[Art Institute of Chicago]]}} '''''Time Transfixed''''' ('''''La Durée poignardée''''') is an [[Oil painting|oil on canvas]] painting by the Belgian [[surrealist]] [[René Magritte]]. It is part of the permanent collection of the [[Art Institute of Chicago]] and is usually on display in the museum's new Modern Wing.<ref name ="AIC1">{{cite web | url = http://www.artic.edu/aic/collections/artwork/34181 | title = About This Artwork | last = Herscovici | first = C | date = 2016 | publisher = The Art Institute of Chicago | access-date = 24 January 2016}}</ref>
The painting was one of many done for surrealist patron and Magritte supporter [[Edward James]]. This was the second painting delivered to James for his London ballroom. The first was the portrait of James, ''[[Not to be Reproduced]]''.<ref name ="AIC2">{{cite web | url = http://www.artic.edu/aic/collections/citi/resources/Rsrc_001110.pdf | title = Time Transfixed | last = Wolf | first = Cori | date = 2001 | publisher = The Art Institute of Chicago | access-date = 24 January 2016}}</ref> ''Time Transfixed'' was purchased by the Art Institute from James in 1970 when he was raising capital to build his surrealist sculpture garden [[Edward_James#Las_Pozas|Las Pozas]].{{cn|date=January 2016}}
The painting depicts an [[London, Midland and Scottish Railway|LMS]]{{cn|date=January 2016}} [[4-6-0|4-6-0 Locomotive]] jutting out of a [[fireplace]], at full steam, in an empty room. Above the mantelpiece is a tall mirror. Only the clock and one candlestick standing on the mantelpiece are reflected in the [[mirror]].<ref name="AIC2" />
==The artist's perspective== The title of the painting translates to English literally as '''''Ongoing Time Stabbed by a Dagger''''', and Magritte was reportedly unhappy with the generally accepted translation of ''Time Transfixed''.<ref name="AMICA">{{cite web | url = http://www.davidrumsey.com/amica/amico649500-5784.html | title = René Magritte / Time Transfixed / 1938 | website = The AMICA Library | date = 2007 | publisher = Cartography Associates | access-date = 24 January 2016}}</ref> Magritte hoped that James would hang the painting at the base of his staircase so that the train would "stab" guests on their way up to the ballroom. James instead chose to hang the painting above his own fireplace.<ref name="AIC2" />
Magritte described his motivation for this painting: :"I decided to paint the image of a locomotive... In order for its mystery to be evoked, another ''immediately'' familiar image without mystery—the image of a dining room fireplace—was joined."<ref name="AIC2" />

Dissolved (2009) | predecessor = | successor = [[De La Rue]] | foundation = 1810 | founder = | defunct = 2009 | location_city = | location_country = | location = UK | locations = | area_served = | key_people = | industry = Secure printing | products = [[Banknote]]s

Stock and bond certificates | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = | footnotes = | intl = }} [[File:1925 Waterlow sample stamp.jpg|thumbnail|right|A promotional stamp produced in 1925 by Waterlow for the [[British Empire Exhibition]].]] '''Waterlow and Sons Limited''' was a major worldwide engraver of [[currency]], [[postage stamps]], [[stock]]s and bond certificates based in London, Watford and Dunstable in [[England]]. The company was founded as a family business in 1810. It was acquired in 1961 by [[De La Rue]]. ==Early history== Waterlow and Sons originated from the business of James Waterlow, who began producing lithographic copies of legal documents at Birchin Lane in London in 1810. The company gradually grew; it began printing stamps in 1852, and Waterlow' sons Alfred, Walter, [[Sir Sydney Waterlow, 1st Baronet|Sydney]] and Albert joined the business. James Waterlow died in 1876, and the company became a limited-liability company. In 1877, due to a family dispute, the company split, and Alfred and his sons formed Waterlow Bros. & Layton. The two companies later reunited in 1920.{{cite web|title=Waterlow and Sons Limited|work=NMSI|publisher=National Museums of Science & Industry|url=http://collectionsonline.nmsi.ac.uk/detail.php?type=related&kv=2719&t=people|accessdate=10 March 2012}}{{cite web|title=Waterlow and Sons: 1934 Review|url=http://www.gracesguide.co.uk/Waterlow_and_Sons:_1934_Review|work=Grace's Guide|publisher=Grace's Guide|accessdate=10 March 2012}} Based on {{cite book|chapter=Printing by Every Process|title=British Commerce and Industry: The Post-War Transition 1919–1934|publisher=Russell-Square Press|year=1934}} In 1924, the company printed 1, 5 and 10 [[Iranian toman|toman]] banknotes that bore the watermark of [[Lion and Sun]] for the first time.{{Citation|last1=Shargi|first1=Ali|title=ESKENĀS|date=15 December 1998|url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/eskenas|volume=VIII/6|pages=615–624|publisher=Encyclopædia Iranica}} ==Portuguese banknote crisis== {{see|Alves dos Reis}}[[File:Quinhentos Escudos, 1922 - Emissão Alves dos Reis.png|thumb|250px]]Waterlow's was involved in the [[Portuguese Bank Note Crisis]] of 1925. The [[Bank of Portugal|Banco de Portugal]] sued Waterlow & Sons in the [[High Court of Justice|High Court]] in [[London]] because of [[counterfeiting]]. In one of the most complex trials in legal history, the case was finally settled in favour of the Bank in 1932.{{cite web|url=http://eprints.lse.ac.uk/22338/|title=The Effects Of The 1925 Portuguese Bank Note Crisis|last=Wigan|first=Henry|date=February 2004|publisher=Department of Economic History, [[London School of Economics]]|accessdate=2009-03-26}} ==Bank of England banknotes== In 1921 the [[Bank of England]] gained a legal [[monopoly]] on the issue of banknotes in England and Wales, a process that started with the [[Bank Charter Act]] of 1844 when the ability of other banks to issues notes was restricted. On 22 November 1928 the Bank issued notes for ten [[shilling]]s and one pound for the first time when the Bank took over responsibility for these denominations from the Treasury which had issued notes of these denominations three days after the declaration of [[World War I|war]] in 1914 in order to remove gold [[coin]]s from circulation. The treasury bills had been printed by Waterlows, and the loss of the contract contributed to the closure of Waterlow's operations at Milton Street in [[Watford]].{{cite book|last=Nunn|first=JB|title=The Book of Watford|publisher=Pageprint (Watford) Ltd|location=Watford|year=1987|isbn=0-9511777-1-0}} p171 ==De La Rue ownership== Waterlow's was acquired by [[Purnell and Sons]] in 1961, but Purnell sold Waterlow's segment that printed banknotes, postage stamps, traveler's checks, and bonds to [[De La Rue]] soon after.{{cite book|last=Bloom|first=Murray Teigh|title=The Man Who Stole Portugal|publisher=Charles Scribner's Sons|location=New York|year=1966}} In 2003 De La Rue acquired the [[banknote]] printing operations of the Bank of England,[http://www.bankofengland.co.uk/publications/news/2003/041.htm Bank of England: Sale of Bank Note Printing Operations] 75 years after Waterlow's had lost the business.
